Answer: A: They are active Cascade volcanoes fed by subduction of an oceanic plate beneath North America.
Explanation: The arrows in the map indicate the location of two prominent volcanoes in California, Mount Shasta and Lassen Peak. These mountains are part of the Cascades volcanic range, which is formed by the subduction of the Juan de Fuca Plate beneath the North American Plate. This subduction process brings hot, molten rock from the mantle up to the surface, forming volcanoes like Mount Shasta and Lassen Peak.
